awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Next Generation Functional Methods for the Analysis of Emerging Repeated Measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop new statistical methods for the analysis of data structures that are correlated. A motivating example is a longitudinal neuroimaging clinical study of Multiple Sclerosis, where the focus is to study the natural evolution/dynamics of the disease over time. Patients are observed at multiple hospital visits, and the disease status is measured through a brain measurement, such as a one-dimensional brain summary or a three-dimensional brain scan. This work will be used: (i) to predict specific brain measurement at a future time; (ii) to assess the dependence between the brain measurement and age, and (iii) to quantify the association between a cognitive assessment and the specific brain measurement. The new statistical methods will be relevant to many other applications, including medicine, economics, environmetrics, and agriculture; they will allow scientists to analyze such data structures using methods that are theoretically sound, interpretable, and easily accessible. The proposed methods make major contributions to the area of functional data analysis and will impact other areas of statistical applications, such as brain imaging and dynamic treatment regimes. The integration of the research with education will impact society at various levels. The investigator will implement an educational initiative to increase exposure of middle-school and high-school students to exciting statistical methods, through hands-on project-related activities, and will increase exposure of undergraduate students to cutting-edge research in statistics.  The investigator's outreach initiative to developing countries through teaching of functional data techniques is valuable for the advancement of all societies through the sharing and dissemination of knowledge.

The development of the next generation statistical methods for the analysis of correlated data structures is necessary because of a longitudinal-based design: each subject is observed at repeated time visits and for each visit we record a functional variable, in addition to other scalar or vector variables. The project meets the growing demand for pragmatic and data efficient statistical methods for such complex data. Two situations are studied: a) the functional variables are the response of interest and b) the functional variables are predictors and another scalar variable is the response. In both cases, accounting for the dependence within the subject as well as for the longitudinal design is crucial for modeling and inference. However, current methods either ignore the dependence or are too complicated and computationally intensive. The specific research goals of this project are: 1) to introduce novel parsimonious modeling framework for the repeatedly observed functional variables, which allows to extract low dimensional features and use them to study the process dynamics; 2) to develop significance tests to formally assess the effect of covariates; and 3) to develop association models and inferential procedures when the functional variables are predictors and another scalar variable is the response observed in a longitudinal design.

por.por_cntn:
Due to rapid advancement in technology many scientific fields are witnessing an unprecedented data revolution. This award focused on scientific applications that collect data where the basic measurement is a function or an image that can be sampled at multiple timepoints. The ultimate goals of the award are to develop statistical inferential methods that precisely address hard scientific questions,  to develop methods and computational tools that take full advantage of the rich information contained in the data, and to propose a class of statistical models that opens a new area of research. The methods were motivated by and applied to relevant and critical challenges from neuroimaging clinical studies, circadian rhythm studies, animal studies, environmental studies, among others. During the lifespan of the award we have developed many innovative statistical methods for modeling, prediction, estimation, and inference for such complex data structures. We briefly discuss our key contributions.  

First, we introduced a parsimonious modeling framework and associated theoretical study for repeatedly measured functional observations. The proposed models characterize process dynamics and predict future functional measurements for longitudinal functional data. Visualization tools that allow for the methods to be readily accessible by practitioners have been also developed. The techniques have been applied to a diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) study, where functional outcomes, such as fractional anisotropy profile across corpus callous or CCA-FA, are measured for multiple sclerosis (MS) patients observed at several hospital visits, with the goal to investigate how the typical behavior of the CCA-FA profile changes for MS patients over the course of four years and to make accurate predictions of the CCA-FA profile of a MS patient at their following hospital visit. The methods have been published in journals like Stat,  Journal of the Royal Statistical Society Series C, Atmospheric Environment; in some case they were showcased at the largest statistical conference (Joint Statistical Meeting, or JSM).  

Second, we proposed inferential methods to formally assess hypotheses about the population mean trend and study subject-specific effect of covariates, when the outcomes or responses are repeatedly measured functional observations. The PI, her collaborators, and students supported by this award proposed novel directions to formally assess complex hypotheses, developed significance tests, and presented their theoretical properties. The testing methods are both very powerful and computationally efficient, and their advantage over alternative approaches is shown numerically through various simulation studies. Methods from this research were applied to two animal studies: a study of arthritis in older cats using accelerometer data on cats observed minute-by-minute over tens of days and a sows study to investigate the association between daily minute-by-minute temperature profiles and feed intake in sows, during their lactation period.  This research contributed to the PhD theses of a couple of doctoral students and the central methods were described in a few manuscripts that are currently under journal review.   

Third, this award developed flexible, yet computationally feasible association models for functional predictors, when the outcome is either scalar or functional. This part was published in journals like Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics, Annals of Applied Statistics, and Journal of  the American Statistical Association and received prestigious research awards (e.g. American Statistical Association Statistics in Physical Engineering Sciences, or SPES, best paper award). Numerous innovations from the proposed methods have the potential to significantly impact other areas in the field of statistics, such as  dynamic treatment regimes. In addition to publications, the results of this award have been also disseminated through participation in seminars, workshops, national and international conferences. Software implementing the methods of this award has been developed and made publicly available to practitioners and fellow researchers.  

This award created an opportunity for the PI to integrate the proposed research into her educational activities, which impacted the society at several levels.  First, the PI?s outreach initiative through the Science and Math Interactive Learning Experiences, or SMILE, camp exposed the K12 students to improved statistical training and the one-year long program - Data Scientists in Training program -  exposed high schoolers and teachers to advanced training in statistical methods needed to address complex but relevant problems, as the ones motivating this award. In particular, as testament of the success of the one-year long program, the PI was recently asked to explore ways to continue offering this training opportunity to both high schoolers and teachers. Second, through her mentoring of undergraduate students, she increased exposure to graduate education in Statistics and advance diversity.  Third, the PI's mentoring and teaching of graduate students, in particular students of diverse backgrounds, is beneficial for students in preparing their future careers in academics, government, and industry.  Fourth, the PI's outreach initiative to developing countries is valuable for the advancement of all societies through the sharing of knowledge.
